list.title: Question 1
list.content:
Let $f(x)=x4+5x3+ax2+bx+2$, for $x∈R$, where $a,b$ are
constants. The remainder when $f(x)$ is divided by $(x−1)$ is $6$, and
the remainder when $f(x)$ is divided by $(x+2)$ is $−6$. Find the value
of $a$ and the value of $b$.
list.markScheme:
Using the remainder theorem, we have
$$$f(1)14+5(1)3+a(1)2+b(1)+21+5+a+b+2a+b​=6=6=6=−2(1)​$$$
and
$$$f(−2)(−2)4+5(−2)3+a(−2)2+b(−2)+216−40+4a−2b+24a−2b​=−6=−6=−6=16(2)​$$$
Hence, solving the
system of linear equations (1)-(2) for $a$ and $b$, we get
$$$a=2​ and b=−4​​$$$

list.title: Question 2
list.content:
When the resulting product of $3x2+7x−6$ multiplied by $ax+1$ is divided by $x−1$ the remainder is $−4$.
Find the integer $a$.
list.markScheme:
Although not essential, we may notice that we can factorise the quadratic expression
$$$3x2+7x−6​=(3x−2)(x+3)​$$$
We will let the the product of the quadratic and linear expression be $p(x)$, hence
$$$p(x)​=(3x−2)(x+3)(ax+1)​(M1)​$$$
Now let's consider dividing $p(x)$ by $x−1$.
Using the remainder theorem we can form an equation
$$$p(1)​=−4​(M1)​$$$
Hence substituting $x=1$ into $p(x)$ the L.H.S. of above becomes
$$$(3(1)−2)(1+3)(a(1)+1)​=−4​A1​$$$
We can now solve this for $a$
$$$1×4×(a+1)a+1a​=−4=−1=−2​​A1​$$$

list.title: Question 3
list.content:
Given that $(x−4)$ is a factor of $f(x)=x3−2x2+ax+b$ and that
division of $f(x)$ by $(x+2)$ leaves a remainder of $18$, find the value
of $a$ and the value of $b$.
list.markScheme:
Using the factor theorem, we get
$$$f(4)43−2(4)2+a(4)+b32+4a+b4a+b​=0=0=0=−32(1)​$$$
Using the remainder
theorem, we obtain
$$$f(−2)(−2)3−2(−2)2+a(−2)+b−16−2a+b−2a+b​=18=18=18=34(2)​$$$
Hence, solving the
system of two linear equations $(1)$-$(2)$ for $a$ and $b$, we find
$$$a=−11​ and b=12​​$$$

list.title: Question 6
list.content:
The polynomial $p(x)=2x4+a3​x3+a2​x2+a1​x−12$ is divisible
by each of $(x+1)$, $(x−1)$ and $(x−2)$.
Find the values of $a1​$, $a2​$ and $a3​$.
list.markScheme:
Using the factor theorem, we have
$$$p(−1)=p(1)=p(2)​=0​$$$
Hence $−1$, $1$ and $2$ are
roots of $p(x)$. Let $x4​$ be the fourth root of $p(x)$.
Using Vieta's formula, we get
$$$(−1)(1)(2)x4​−2x4​−2x4​x4​​=(−1)4[a4​a0​​]=2(−12)​=−6=3​$$$
Hence we obtain
$$$p(x)​=2(x+1)(x−1)(x−2)(x−3)=2(x2−1)(x2−5x+6)=2x4−10x3+10x2+10x−12​$$$
Hence we find
$a1​=a2​=10​$
and  $a3​=−10​$

list.title: Question 7
list.content:
When $p(x)=x2−2x+p$ is divided by $x−r$, the remainder is $4$.
Given that $p,r∈R$, find the largest possible value for
$p$.
list.markScheme:
Using the remainder theorem, we have
$$$p(r)r2−2r+p​=4=4​$$$
If we rewrite the equation
$(1)$, we get
$$$pppp​=−r2+2r+4=−[r2−2r]+4=−[(r−1)2−1]+4=−(r−1)2+5​$$$
Hence the largest possible value for
$p$ is
$$$pmax​​=−(1−1)2+5[when r=1]=0+5=5​​$$$

list.title: Question 10
list.content:
Consider the polynomial $p(z)=z5+z4−z3+z2+4z+2$, for
$z∈C$.


Write down the sum and product of the roots of $p(z)=0$.
[2]



Show that $(z+1)$ is a factor of $p(z)$. [2]



The polynomial can be written in the form
$p(z)=(z+1)3(z2+cz+d)$.


Find the value of $c$ and the value of $d$. [5]



Hence find the complex roots of $p(z)=0$. [3]
list.markScheme:
Using Vieta's formulas, we have
$$$sum of roots​=−a5​a4​​=−11​=−1​​$$$
and
$$$product of roots​=(−1)5[a5​a0​​]=−12​=−2​​$$$


Evaluating $p(z)$ for $z=−1$, we have
$$$p(−1)​=(−1)5+(−1)4−(−1)3+(−1)2+4(−1)+2=0​$$$
Hence, by factor theorem, $(z+1)$ is a factor of
$p(z)$.


Evaluating $p(z)$ for $z=0$ and $z=1$, we have $p(0)=2$ and
$p(1)=8$.
Hence, substituting $z=0,1$ in the equation
$p(z)=(z+1)3(z2+cz+d)$, we get
$$$p(0)2​=(0+1)3(02+c(0)+d)=d​$$$
$$$d=2​$$$
and
$$$p(1)8​=(1+1)3(12+c(1)+2)=8(c+3)​$$$
$$$c=−2​$$$


The complex roots of $p(z)=0$ are the complex roots of
$z2−2z+2=0$.
Hence, using the quadratic formula, we find
$$$z​=2(1)−(−2)±22−4(1)(2)​​=22±2i​=1±i​​$$$

list.title: Question 12
list.content:
When $p(x)=x2−2x−c$ is divided by $(x−r)$, the remainder is
$−5$.
Given that $c,r∈R$, find the smallest possible value for
$c$.
list.markScheme:
Using the remainder theorem, we have
$$$p(r)r2−2r−c​=−5=−5(1)​$$$
If we rewrite
the equation $(1)$, we get
$$$c​=r2−2r+5=[(r−1)2−1]+5=(r−1)2+4​$$$
Hence the smallest possible value for
$c$ is
$$$cmin​​=(1−1)2+4[when r=1]=0+4=4​​$$$

list.title: Question 13
list.content:
Let $f(x)=ax3+bx2+cx+d$, for $x∈R$, where
$a,b,c,d∈Q$. The diagram below shows part of the graph of
$y=f(x)$.


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/d78a10f2-621e-426c-91f2-9dea87dbacc5/images/89842500-91d4-4b78-a494-6ce2510b4acf/f2e9d58912ae2f10d7fdf9d12ee3b7594c2c45fb.svg)




Using the information shown in the diagram, find the values of $a$,
$b$, $c$ and $d$.[4]



Let $g(x)=−43​f(−2x+1)$.


Find the coordinates of the points where the graph of $y=g(x)$
intercepts the $x$-axis.


Find the $y$-intercept of the graph of $y=g(x)$. [3]
list.markScheme:
From the diagram, we see that the roots of the polynomial equation
$f(x)=0$ are $−3$, $−1$ and $3$.
Hence, using the factor theorem, we have
$$$f(x)​=a(x−3)(x+1)(x+3)=a(x2−9)(x+1)=a(x3+x2−9x−9)(1)​$$$
If we substitute
$x=0$ in the expression $(1)$, we get
$$$f(0)−3a​=a(03+02−9(0)−9)=−9a[since f(0)=−3]=31​​$$$
If we substitute $a=1/3$ in the
expression $(1)$, we obtain
$$$f(x)​=31​(x3+x2−9x−9)=31​x3+31​x2−3x−3​$$$
Hence we find
$a=b=31​​$
and  $c=d=−3​$




Solving the equation $g(x)=0$ for $x$, we find
$$$−43​f(−2x+1)f(−2x+1)−2x+1−2xx​=0=0=−3,−1,3=−4,−2,2=−1,1,2​$$$
Hence
the coordinates of the $x$-intercepts of the graph of $y=g(x)$
are
$$$(−1,0),(1,0),(2,0)​​$$$


Evaluating $y=g(x)$ for $x=0$, we find
$$$y​=g(0)=−43​f(2(0)+1)=−43​f(1)=−43​[31​(1)3+31​(1)2−3(1)−3]=−43​[−316​]=4​$$$
Hence the $y$-intercept of the graph of
$y=g(x)$ is
$P(0,4)​$

list.title: Question 14
list.content:
Consider the equation $2z4+az3+bz2+cz+d=0$, where
$a,b,c,d∈R$ and $z∈C$. Two of the roots of
the equation are $log2​10$ and
$i5​$ and the sum of all the
roots is $4+log2​5$.
Show that $15a+d+90=0$.
list.markScheme:
Since $i5​$ is a root, its
conjugate $−i5​$ is also a
root of the equation.
If $z4​$ is the fourth root of the equation, we have
$$$i5​​+(−i5​​)+log2​10+z4​z4​z4​z4​z4​​=4+log2​5[sum of roots]=4+log2​5−log2​10=4+log2​5​−(log2​2+log2​5​)=4−1[since log2​2=1]=3​$$$
Using Vieta's formulas, we have
$$$−2a​a​=4+log2​5[sum of roots]=−8−2log2​5​$$$
and
$$$(−1)4[2d​]d​=(i5​)(−i5​)(log2​10)(3)[product of roots]=30log2​10​$$$
Hence we get
$$$15a+d+90​=15(−8−2log2​5)+30log2​10+90=−120−30log2​5​+30log2​2+30log2​5​+90=−120+30+90[since log2​2=1]=0​​$$$

list.title: Question 15
list.content:

Given that $x2+x−2$ is a factor of $f(x)$, find the values of

Hence, solving the system of
two linear equations $(1)$-$(2)$ for $a$ and $b$, we find
$$$a=−3​ and b=−8​​$$$

list.content:
Let $p(x)=41​x5−2x4−5x3+40x2+16x−128$, for

For the polynomial equation $p(x)=0$, state:

A new polynomial is defined by $q(x)=p(2x−2)$.

For the polynomial equation $q(x)=0$, find:

Using Vieta's formulas, we have:


the sum of the roots of $p(x)=0$ is
$$$−a5​a4​​​=−1/4(−2)​=8​​$$$


the product of the roots of $p(x)=0$ is
$$$(−1)5[a5​a0​​]​=−1/4(−128)​=512​​$$$




We have

Hence, using Vieta's formulas, we have:

the product of the roots of $q(x)=0$ is

list.title: Question 17
list.content:
Consider the family of polynomials of the form $P(x)=ax3+bx2+cx+d$ where coefficients $a$, $b$, $c$ and $d$ belong to the set ${2,6,8,24}$.


Find the number of possible polynomials if


each coefficient value can be repeated;


each coefficient must be different.[4]





Consider the case where $P(x)$ has $x+3$ as a factor, two purely imaginary roots, and all the coefficients are different.




By considering the sum of the roots, find the two possible combinations for coefficients $a$ and $b$.


Show that there is only one way to assign the values $a$, $b$, $c$, and $d$ if $P(0)=24$.[7]





Now, consider the polynomial with the coefficients found in part (b) (ii).




Express $P(x)$ as a product of one linear and one quadratic factor.


Determine the three roots of $P(x)$.[7]
list.markScheme:
Let $X$ be the total number of polynomials.


Given that each coefficient value can be repeated, we have
$$$X​=4×4×4×4=44=256.​$$$
Therefore, there are $256​$ possible polynomials if the coefficients can be repeated.


Given that each coefficient must be different, we have
$$$X​=4!=4×3×2×1=24.​$$$
Therefore, there are $24​$ possible polynomials if each coefficient must be different.






Let the roots be $x1​,x2​$ and $x3​$. Given that $x+3$ is a factor, $x1​=−3$ is a root. Complex roots occur in conjugate pairs, therefore if the other two roots are imaginary, we have $x2​=αi$ and $x3​=−αi$, where $α∈R$. Hence, the sum of the roots is given by
$$$x1​+x2​+x3​​=−3+αi−αi=−3​$$$
Using the formula for the sum of the roots, we have
$$$x1​+x2​+x3​−33a​=−ab​=−ab​=b​$$$
We have that $a$ and $b$ belong to the set ${2,6,8,24}$ and $3a=b$. Therefore,
$The two possible combinations are a=2,b=6 and a=8,b=24.​$


If $P(0)=24$, we have
$$$P(0)24​=a(0)3+b(0)2+c(0)+d=d​$$$
The coefficients must all be different. If $d=24$, $b=24$, so we have from part (b)(i) that $a=2$ and $b=6$. Therefore $c=8$.
$If P(0)=24, we must have a=2,b=6,c=8 and d=24.​$






Our polynomial is $P(x)=2x3+6x2+8x+24$. Given that $x+3$ is a factor, we have
$$$2x3+6x2+8x+242x3+6x2+8x+24​=(x+3)(2x2+ex+8)=2x3+ex2+8x+6x2+3ex+24=2x3+(e+6)x2+(8+3e)x+24​$$$
Equating the coefficients of $x2$ and $x$ on the LHS and RHS, we have
$$$68​=e+6=8+3e​$$$
We must have $e=0$. Therefore
$$$P(x)​=(x+3)(2x2+8)P(x)=2(x+3)(x2+4)​​$$$


We have from part (b)(i) that $x1​=−3$. To find the other two roots, we solve $x2+4=0$:
$$$x2+4x2xx​=0=−4=±−4​=±2i​$$$
$The roots of P(x) are x1​=−3,x2​=−2i, and x3​=2i.​$

Hence
$$$​f′(x)−L′(x)=3a(x−x1​)(x−β) for some β​​$$$


Integrating $f(x)−L(x)$ with respect to $x$, we get
$$$∫3a(x−x1​)(x−β)dx​=3a∫(x−x1​)(x−β)dx=3a[21​(x−x1​)2(x−β)−∫21​(x−x1​)2dx]=23a​(x−x1​)2(x−β)−2a​(x−x1​)3+C​M1A1​$$$
But using that $f(x)−L(x)=0$, we get that $C=0$. Therefore,
$$$f(x)−L(x)​=23a​(x−x1​)2(x−β)−2a​(x−x1​)3=2a​(x−x1​)2(3x−3β−x+x1​)=2a​(x−x1​)2(2x+x1​−3β)​​A1​$$$


Let the other intersection point occur at $x=x3​$. Hence, we get
$$$f(x)−L(x)​=a(x−x1​)2(x−x3​)​M1​$$$
using (b)(ii) $x∗​$ can be written as
$$$x1​+x1​+x3​​=3x∗​x3​=3x∗​−2x1​​​A1​$$$

list.title: Question 19
list.content:
Show that $cos3θ=4cos3θ−3cosθ$. [4]


Consider the following function
$$$f(x)​=4x3−3x−cos3k​$$$
Where $k$ is an angle in degrees such that $0≤k≤360∘$.

Hence, verify that $cosk$ is one of the roots of $f(x)$.[2]


Let the remaining two roots of $f(x)$ be $α$ and $β$.




Find $αβ$ in terms of $cosk$.


Show that $β=−α−cosk$.[3]





Using your answers from part (c) show that $α2+αcosk+cos2k−43​=0$. [2]



Hence show that $α=2−cosk+3​sink​$ and $β=2−cosk−3​sink​$. [4]



It is known that for $0≤k≤360∘$ $f(x)$ has either $3$ distinct roots or a single distinct root and a repeated root.

Hence, find all of the values of $k$ for which $f(x)$ intersects the $x−$axis exactly $2$ times. [7]
list.markScheme:
Using the compound angle identity from the formula booklet we can write
$$$cos(A+B)cos(2θ+θ)cos3θ​=cosAcosB−sinAsinB=cos2θcosθ−sin2θsinθ=cos2θcosθ−sin2θsinθ​M1A1​$$$
We can now the use the double angle formula to rewrite $cos2θ$ and $sin2θ$ in terms of single angle functions.
$$$cos3θ​=(2cos2θ−1)cosθ−(2sinθcosθ)sinθ=2cos3θ−cosθ−2sin2θcosθ​M1​$$$
Now rewrite $sin2θ$ in terms of $cosθ$.
$$$cos3θ​=2cos3θ−cosθ−2(1−cos2θ)cosθ=2cos3θ−cosθ−2cosθ+2cos3θ=4cos3θ−3cosθ​... as required.​M1​$$$


If $cosk$ is a root of $f(x)$ then $f(cosk)=0$.
$$$hack​A1​$$$
$$$f(cosk)​=4(cosk)3−3(cosk)−cos3k​$$$
Using part (a)
$$$f(cosk)​=cos3k−cos3k=0​M1​$$$
Hence, $cosk is a root of f(x)​$



Using the formula for the product of the roots of a polynomial
$$$αβcosk​=−4(−1)3cos3k​​M1​$$$
Using part (a) we can rewrite $cos3k$
$$$αβcoskαβ​=44cos3k−3cosk​=44cos2k−3​=cos2k−43​​​A1​$$$

Using the formula for the sum of the roots of a polynomial (with the coefficient of $x2$ being $0$)
$$$α+β+coskβ=−α−cosk​​=−40​​A1​$$$




Combining our answers from part (c)
$$$αβα(−α−cosk)−α2−αcosk​=cos2k−43​β=−α−cosk=cos2k−43​=cos2k−43​0=α2+αcosk+cos2k−43​​... as required​(M1)A1​$$$


Use the quadratic formula with $a=1,b=cosk$ and $c=cos2k−43​$
$$$hack​A1​$$$
$$$α​=2−cosk±cos2k−4×1×(cos2k−43​)​​=2−cosk±cos2k−4cos2k+3)​​=2−cosk±−3cos2k+3)​​=2−cosk±3(1−cos2k)​​=2−cosk±3sin2k​​=2−cosk±3​sink​​A1​$$$
Let $α=2−cosk+3​sink​$, using the answer from part (c) (ii) we can find $β$
$$$hack​M1​$$$
$$$β​=−α−cosk=−2−cosk+3​sink​−cosk=2cosk−3​sink​−22cosk​=2−cosk−3​sink​​$$$
Hence $α=2−cosk+3​sink​ and β=2−cosk−3​sink​​$
$$$hack​A1​$$$
Note: also accept vice versa solutions for $α$ and $β$.


$f(x)$ must have a single distinct root and a repeated root to intersect the $x−$axis exactly twice.
Recall the three roots to $f(x)$ are $α,β$ and $cosk$.
We have a repeated root when any of these conditions are met.
$$$hack​M1​$$$
$$$ααβ​=β=cosk=cosk​[1][2][3]​$$$
Let's consider condition $[1]$ first
$$$α2−cosk+3​sink​23​sink​sinkk​=β=2−cosk−3​sink​=−23​sink​=0 where 0≤k≤360∘=0,180∘,360∘​M1A1​$$$
Now consider condition $[2]$
$$$α2−cosk+3​sink​2−cosk+3​sink​2−3cosk+3​sink​3​sinktankk​=cosk=cosk=22cosk​=0=3cosk=3​ where 0≤k≤360∘=60∘,240∘​M1A1​$$$
Finally consider condition $[3]$
$$$β2−cosk−3​sink​tankk​=cosk=cosk=−3​ where 0≤k≤360∘=120∘,300∘​M1A1​$$$
Hence $f(x)$ will intersect the $x−$axis exactly $2$ times when
$$$k=0∘,60∘,120∘,180∘,240∘,300∘,360∘​​$$$

list.title: Question 20
list.content:
The cubic polynomial equation $x3+bx2+cx+d=0$ has three roots
$x1​,x2​$ and $x3​$. By expanding the product $(x−x1​)(x−x2​)(x−x3​)$,
show that




$b=−(x1​+x2​+x3​)$;


$c=x1​x2​+x1​x3​+x2​x3​$;


$d=−x1​x2​x3​$. [3]





It is given that $b=−9$ and $c=45$ for parts (b) and (c) below.




In the case that the three roots $x1​,x2​$ and $x3​$ form an
arithmetic
sequence, show that one of the roots is $3$.


Hence determine the value of $d$. [5]





In another case the three roots form a geometric sequence.
Determine
the value of $d$. [6]
list.markScheme:
Given the three roots $x1​$, $x2​$ and $x3​$, we have
$$$x3+bx2+cx+d​=(x−x1​)(x−x2​)(x−x3​)=(x2−(x1​+x2​)x+x1​x2​)(x−x3​)=x3−(x1​+x2​+x3​)x2+(x1​x2​+x1​x3​+x2​x3​)x−x1​x2​x3​​$$$
Hence, comparing the coefficients, we get


$b=−(x1​+x2​+x3​)​$


$c=x1​x2​+x1​x3​+x2​x3​​$


$d=−x1​x2​x3​​$






Letting $α=x1​+δ$, where $δ$ is the common
difference of the arithmetic sequence $x1​$, $x2​$, $x3​$, we
have
$$$x1​x2​x3​​=α−δ=α=α+δ​$$$
Hence, using part (a)
(i), we get
$$$x1​+x2​+x3​(α−δ)+α+(α+δ)3αα​=−b=−(−9)=9=3​$$$
$$$x2​=3​$$$


Using part (a) (ii), we have
$$$x1​x2​+x1​x3​+x2​x3​(3−δ)(3)+(3−δ)(3+δ)+(3)(3+δ)27−δ2−δ2δ​=c=45=45=18=18​i​$$$
Hence, using part (a) (iii), we get
$$$d​=−x1​x2​x3​=−(3−18​i)(3)(3+18​i)=−81​​$$$




Letting $α=x1​$ and $r$ denote the common ratio of the
geometric sequence $x1​,x2​,x3​$, we have
$$$x1​x2​x3​​=α=αr=αr2​$$$
Hence we get
$$$x1​+x2​+x3​α+αr+αr2α(1+r+r2)​=−b[by part (a) (i)]=−(−9)=9(1)​$$$
and
$$$x1​x2​+x1​x3​+x2​x3​α(αr)+α(αr2)+(αr)(αr2)α2r(1+r+r2)​=c[by part (a) (ii)]=45=45(2)​$$$
Taking the ratio
of the expressions $(1)$ and $(2)$, we obtain
$$$α(1+r+r2​)α2r(1+r+r2​)​αα2r​αr​=945​=945​=5(3)​$$$
Hence, using the expression $(3)$, we find
$$$d​=−x1​x2​x3​[by (a) (iii)]=−α(αr)(αr2)=−(αr)3=−53=−125​​$$$
